title: [QUESTION] (dev/update-skia) Wrong naming in new SkColorType members?
body:
The `dev/update-skia` branch has new `SkColorType` members:

```cs
	public enum SKColorType
	{
		Unknown = 0,
		Alpha8 = 1,
		Rgb565 = 2,
		Argb4444 = 3,
		Rgba8888 = 4,
		Rgb888x = 5,
		Bgra8888 = 6,
		Rgba1010102 = 7,
		Rgb101010x = 8,
		Gray8 = 9,
		RgbaF16 = 10,
                // vvv NEW vvv
		RgbaF16Normalized = 11,
		RgbaF32 = 12,
		R8g8Unnormalized = 13,
		A16Float = 14,
		R16g16Float = 15,
		A16Unnormalized = 16,
		R16g16Unnormalized = 17,
		R16g16b16a16Unnormalized = 18,
	}
```

These correspond to Skia's 

```cpp
enum SkColorType {
    kUnknown_SkColorType,      //!< uninitialized
    kAlpha_8_SkColorType,      //!< pixel with alpha in 8-bit byte
    kRGB_565_SkColorType,      //!< pixel with 5 bits red, 6 bits green, 5 bits blue, in 16-bit word
    kARGB_4444_SkColorType,    //!< pixel with 4 bits for alpha, red, green, blue; in 16-bit word
    kRGBA_8888_SkColorType,    //!< pixel with 8 bits for red, green, blue, alpha; in 32-bit word
    kRGB_888x_SkColorType,     //!< pixel with 8 bits each for red, green, blue; in 32-bit word
    kBGRA_8888_SkColorType,    //!< pixel with 8 bits for blue, green, red, alpha; in 32-bit word
    kRGBA_1010102_SkColorType, //!< 10 bits for red, green, blue; 2 bits for alpha; in 32-bit word
    kBGRA_1010102_SkColorType, //!< 10 bits for blue, green, red; 2 bits for alpha; in 32-bit word
    kRGB_101010x_SkColorType,  //!< pixel with 10 bits each for red, green, blue; in 32-bit word
    kBGR_101010x_SkColorType,  //!< pixel with 10 bits each for blue, green, red; in 32-bit word
    kGray_8_SkColorType,       //!< pixel with grayscale level in 8-bit byte
    kRGBA_F16Norm_SkColorType, //!< pixel with half floats in [0,1] for red, green, blue, alpha; in 64-bit word
    kRGBA_F16_SkColorType,     //!< pixel with half floats for red, green, blue, alpha; in 64-bit word
    kRGBA_F32_SkColorType,     //!< pixel using C float for red, green, blue, alpha; in 128-bit word

    // The following 6 colortypes are just for reading from - not for rendering to
    kR8G8_unorm_SkColorType,   //<! pixel with a uint8_t for red and green

    kA16_float_SkColorType,    //<! pixel with a half float for alpha
    kR16G16_float_SkColorType, //<! pixel with a half float for red and green

    kA16_unorm_SkColorType,    //<! pixel with a little endian uint16_t for alpha
    kR16G16_unorm_SkColorType, //<! pixel with a little endian uint16_t for red and green
    kR16G16B16A16_unorm_SkColorType,//<! pixel with a little endian uint16_t for red, green, blue, and alpha
```

However, the `unorm` in the C++ Skia API means `unsigned normalized`, not `un-normalized`

Maybe `Unnormalized` means unsigned normalized, but in the industry, `UNORM` and `SNORM` are the naming conventions.

Also - at least in OpenGL - `UNORM` is the standard, so not explicitly mentioned. `SNORM` is non-standard, and explicitly mentioned. 

The existing color types in  SkiaSharp v1.68 are actually all `UNORM`, but this is not mentioned in the name. E.g.  `Bgra8888` is actually an `UNORM` 8-bit unsigned integer. 

One exception though, the `SkColorType.RgbaF16` in v1.68 is actually **not** normalized at all... The new `RgbaF16Normalized` is, but `normalized` here means something different, since the floating point numbers are not [normalized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normalization_(image_processing)), but rather just **clamped** between `[0..1]`...  So maybe `SkColorType.RgbaF16Clamped` would be a better way to describe this? I'm not 100% sure this is correct, maybe `kRGBA_F16Norm_SkColorType` does something different...

Since the new members are not yet in `master`, maybe the C# API could use a more consistent naming? I would just drop the `unnormalized` in the name, but I'm not sure what to do with the floating point related members...

Tricky.
